mods.abstract: Letter ordering an officer to go with a guard of one non-commissioned officer and six men in order to take charge of a passenger train on the Rome Railroad; the letter includes additional instructions. An example of the form to be kept is hand-drawn at the bottom of first page. The letter is signed by Captain and Provost Marshal J. P. Baltzelle.

relatedItem.identifier: [Page 1 of 2] Provost Marshall Office Kingston Ga Nov 1863 Sir You will with your guard of one non commissioned officer and six men take charge of the Passenger Train on the Rome Rail Road and procede (sp) until further orders from Kingston to Rome Ga and return – observing the following instructions. Examine the Pass-ports Orders, Furloughs, &c. of all persons, Citizens or Soldiers, male or female traveling on the Road, permit no citizens on the trains unless provided with Pass-ports – arrest all officers or soldiers absent from their commands without proper authority, those arrested on upward bound trains you will turn over to Provost Marshall, at Rome, those arrested on down trains you will report to this office. Record the name, Rank, Regt, Co, and nature of Papers, of all officers or Soldiers traveling on the Road, also at what Station they take passage, and to what station they go, using the following form Rome R. R. ___ Date ________ 1863 Rank | Name | Report | Co. | From | To | on what papers | Remarks | ____________________________________________________________ Signed Officers Signature Day or night Train Deliver to the Officer of the Guard at Rome the list thus made, and receive from him his record of the Passengers on the train on which you may return, which record you will deposit in this office on arrival. [Page 2 of 2] No officer or Soldier belonging to the Army of Tenn, is permitted to leave the lines of the army unless their papers are approved at Hd. Qrs. army Tenn. All officers or soldiers found on the train without such authority will be arrested. Sick men, when placed on trains to go to Hospitals, must have the certificate of the Post Surgeon, of the Post at which they may take passage. No soldier is permitted to take with him his arms or accoutrements, when leaving the Army. All arms will be taken from such men turned over to the Ordinance officer. You will suppress disorder, interdict the use or introduction of intoxicating liquors on the cars, or its sale at any of the stations on the Road. Arrest all the intoxicated or disorderly persons. In loading trains at Atlanta, you will see that all persons belonging to the army are seated before allowing citizens on the trains. When there is sufficient room, citizens may be admitted in the cars, but Soldiers always take precedence. All citizens leaving Atlanta must have Pass-ports from this office, and no citizen will be permitted to go beyond Dalton Ga, unless provided with Pass-ports from Hd. Qrs. Army of Tenn. You will see that no persons are permitted to stand or sit on the platform of the cars. You will report at this office immediately on arrival and within one hour prior to departure of trains. For officer of Guard, Rome R. R. By order of J. P. Baltzell /Capt. & P. M.

relatedItem.abstract: The images found in this section have been gathered from various manuscript collections and offer a glimpse at the wide variety of material available at the Tennessee State Library and Archives that may be of interest to those researching Civil War history and genealogy. These images illustrate the extensive recordkeeping system at work during the Civil War and demonstrate the complex organizational structure needed to handle the massive accumulation of records. From transportation orders to quartermaster records, these items not only provide insight into the soldiers’ lives, they also illustrate the costs of war and sacrifices that were made from all facets of society on both the Confederate and Federal sides...
